required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Regular Exercise on Maternal Cardiovascular System During Pregnancy
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Supervised Exercise Program on Cardiovascular Function and Structure in Pregnant Women. Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The main aim of this study was to analysed the security of a supervised exercise program on maternal cardiovascular system and assess the positive effects of this program on maternal cardiovascular function and structure

detailed_description.textblock:
During pregnancy, the effectiveness of cardiovascular system is necessary to the growth and development of the baby, however many changes in it occur during this period.
Physical exercise has shown to have a positive effect on cardiovascular structure and function in the general population.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from cardiovascular function at the end of pregnancy: Stroke volume
primary_outcome.description: Data were collected in second and third trimester

primary_outcome.measure: Change from cardiovascular structure at the end of the pregnancy
primary_outcome.description: Data were collected in second and third trimester

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During pregnancy. At the moment of delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Gestational age, type of delivery, duration of labor, maternal weight gain, birth weight, size and head circumference of new born, pH of umbilical cord, Apgar Score.

intervention.description: Supervised physical conditioning program of three 55—60 minute sessions per week during whole pregnancy (from week 9 to 38). Each session consists of 25-30 minutes of cardiovascular exercise,10 minutes of specific exercises (strength and balance exercises), and 10 minutes of pelvic floor muscles training Aerobic activity was prescribed at light to moderate intensity, aiming for 55-60 of maximal heart rate. All subjects wore a heart rate (HR) monitor (Polar FT7) during the training sessions to ensure that exercise intensity was light to moderate.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Being healthy and able to exercise following American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) guidelines
- Being able to communicate in spanish
- Giving birth at Hospital Universitario de Fuenlabrada and Hospital Universitario Severo Ochoa (Madrid).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Multiparity
- Obstetrician complications
- Being interested in the study after 18 weeks
- Not being regular in physical exercise program
- Younger than 18 years old
